8C6644551C654D4BA0BFC97E530B3423.description:
Communication and Teamwork: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

standardize an acidic or a basic solution and compare group results 
(PR-NS2)
draw a flowchart for an industrial chemical process 
(CT-ST2)
use integrated software effectively and efficiently to produce work that incorporates data, graphics and text 
(CT-ST2)[ICT P4-4.3]

1B630908487E4316B0F194DF4494BBBF.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions   • calculate theoretical and actual yield and percent yield and error, and account for discrepancies between the theoretical and actual yields 
(AI-NS3)(AI-NS4)[ICT C6-4.1]   • analyze and evaluate experimental data of a precipitation reaction to determine the concentration of a solution 
(AI-NS3)(AI-NS4)(AI-NS6)[ICT C7-4.2]   •graph and analyze titration curves for acid-base experiments restricted to strong monoprotic acid-strong monoprotic base combinations 
(PR-NS4)   • use appropriate SI notation, fundamental and derived units and significant digits when performing stoichiometric calculations 
(CT-ST2)

9D2D4A848F4B423E9BC0D94334305A5D.description:
Performing and Recording: conduct investigations into relationships between and among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information   •  perform a titration to determine the concentration of an acid or a base restricted to strong monoprotic acid-strong monoprotic base combinations 
(PR-NS3)   • use probes and software to collect titration data 
(PR-NS2)[ICT C6-4.4]   • research methods used by industry to reduce emissions 
PR-ST1)[ICT F2-4.4]   • design a prototype of a chemical industrial plant 
(PR-ST2)

FECD2BCD4E1B46E09FF1E03C5E346D1B.description:
Initiating and Planning: formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues   • design a procedure, using crystallization, filtration or titration, to determine the concentration of a solution 
(IP-ST2)   • describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-ST3)   • predict the approximate equivalence point for a strong monoprotic acid-strong monoprotic base titration and select an appropriate indicator 
(IP-NS3)(IP-NS4)

659B3E6E72D74BB4A3DB32FF0A64BDF3.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Science and Technology Emphasis)

89686C0C8DA542B7BCE07AC6A8D5A2D6.description:
explain how the appropriateness, risks and benefits of technologies need to be assessed for each potential application from a variety of perspectives, including sustainability 
(ST7)[ICT F3-4.1]   • assess the significance of specific by-products from industrial, commercial and household chemical reactions   •analyze the use of technologies, such as smokestacks and catalytic converters, to reduce emissions that are harmful to the environment, such as SO2(g) and greenhouse gases.

A8EEAF29AE384668A70E43C7D84B2450.description:
explain that scientific knowledge may lead to the development of new technologies, and new technologies may lead to or facilitate scientific discovery 
(ST4)[ICT F2-4.4]

describe how industries apply principles of stoichiometry to minimize waste and maximize yield

CEE22379E6E6446D9174F58B624E0E35.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

3BF0BCE96FA040E991BCE3BEF8F30270.description: identify equivalence points on strong monoprotic acid-strong monoprotic base titration curves and differentiate between the indicator end point and the equivalence point.

050D4EB3A0774DD9860B385B18422366.description: describe the function and choice of indicators in titrations

9FD0E9C812374E5699C86413A4E3946D.description: draw and interpret titration curves, using data from titration experiments involving strong monoprotic acids and strong monoprotic bases

9DFC0438ED73461BA8E8DB8850D06BBF.description: explain the discrepancy between theoretical and actual yield

4C9745FDC94D4DC8A16435E06E4686D6.description: define theoretical yields and actual yields

A5230B918C2940358B43B05897C3CEB3.description: identify limiting and excess reagents in chemical reactions

A4E4B2D50A394A6A969B6D85E9E414BB.description: explain chemical principles (i.e., conservation of mass in a chemical change), using quantitative analysis

6FADDCA260BF4F899098CE90A8777E82.description: Students will use stoichiometry in quantitative analysis.

AF6ABC1BD8794E308261393F85244747.description:
Communication and Teamwork:  work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

use integrated software effectively and efficiently to incorporate data and text 
(AI-NS3)(CT-ST2)[ICT P4-4.3]

FEE4B924A4D74E38AB6C9BF75D0EB5D0.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions   • interpret stoichiometric ratios from chemical reaction equations 
(AI-ST3)   • perform calculations to determine theoretical yields 
(AI-NS3)[ICT C6-4.1]   • use appropriate SI notation, fundamental and derived units and significant digits when performing stoichiometric calculations

5D6B05F142C1485FAF26D2DBD209F3A7.description:
Performing and Recording:  conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information   • translate word equations for chemical reactions into chemical equations, including states of matter for the products and reactants 
(CT-ST2)   • balance chemical equations for chemical reactions, using lowest whole-number coefficients 
(AI-ST3)

DC52E6F326CF40B59B9663131DF2C71B.description:
Initiating and Planning: formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues  • plan and predict states, products and theoretical yields for chemical reactions 
(IP-NS3)[ICT C6-4.1]  •design an experiment to identify an ion; e.g., precipitation, flame test 
(IP-NS2)  •describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-ST3)

9AF82B08B97A4CD38EE35E71D99A5D3D.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Science and Technology Emphasis)

ED2FC341FDCF48A8BCD30C0D0FC1FA57.description:
explain that the products of technology are devices, systems and processes that meet given needs; however, these products cannot solve all problems (ST6) [ICT F2–4.4]
• analyze the chemical reactions involved in various industrial and commercial
processes and products that use stoichiometric and chemical principles:
− production of urea
− fertilizers
− fuel combustion
− water treatment
− air bag deployment
− neutralization of excess stomach acid.

637152AFE1FC4B5A87B7F57632ECDB18.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

685C7AB6E2E140668C8048541BA09E66.description: calculate the quantities of reactants and/or products involved in chemical reactions, using gravimetric, solution or gas stoichiometry.

43DE5BFD0E5140CD88CAA76B5AD8AE97.description: write balanced ionic and net ionic equations, including identification of spectator ions, for reactions taking place in aqueous solutions

9313D4D98CCC4432A16D828F4016A460.description: recall the balancing of chemical equations in terms of atoms, molecules and moles

B2503DC76A6F41FBA4044C9D5DBE126B.description: predict the product(s) of a chemical reaction based upon the reaction type

E083401BFF2C41E69DC52BFAE9A05123.description: Students will explain how balanced chemical equations indicate the quantitative relationships between reactants and products involved in chemical changes.

7F235818EA4A4379979596084279B80E.description: Unit D: Quantitative Relationships in Chemical Changes

18F03271BC774E39A347EAF7C00F08D5.description:
Communication and Teamwork:  work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results   • research, collectively, the relationship between sulfuric acid and industrialization 
(CT-SEC1)[ICT C1-4.1][ICT C2-4.1]  • evaluate technologies used to reduce emissions that lead to acid deposition 
(CT-SEC1)[ICT C6-4.5]

FB09C4FF52324324BBEC83D25C5FF103.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions   • use indicators to determine the pH for a variety of solutions 
(PR-NS2)(AI-NS6)   •assess, qualitatively, the risks and benefits of producing, using and transporting acidic and basic substances, based on WHMIS and transportation of dangerous goods guidelines 
(AI-ST2)

E2F9266374B94724B1D904FA54EAE4CE.description:
Performing and Recording: conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information   • construct a table or graph to compare pH and hydronium ion concentration, illustrating that as the hydronium ion concentration increases, the pH decreases 
(PR-NS4)  • use a pH meter to determine the acidity and/or alkalinity of a solution 
(PR-NS2)[ICT C6-4.4]

06537E852E8E40E68BE445EECFE855DF.description:
Initiating and Planning: formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues   • design an experiment to differentiate among acidic, basic and neutral solutions 
(IP-NS2)  • design an experiment to differentiate between weak and strong acids and between weak and strong bases 
(IP-NS2)   • describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-ST3)

F92ECB323DA14B79B09DD209E4768474.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Science and Technology Emphasis)

9028307175CB474CB39CFCF19D2F0954.description:
explain that technological problems often require multiple solutions that involve different designs, materials and processes and that have both intended and unintended consequences 
(ST3)[ICT F3-4.1]  • provide examples of processes and products that use knowledge of acid and base chemistry (the pulp and paper industry, the petrochemical industry, food preparation and preservation, cleaning aids, sulfuric acid in car batteries, treating accidental acid or base spills using neutralization and dilution)  • explain the significance of the strength and concentration of solutions in everyday life (pharmaceuticals, chemical spills, transportation of dangerous goods, toxicity)  • identify examples in Alberta in which holistic practices used by some Aboriginal communities can be used to moderate the impact of development in industries such as the petrochemical industry.

5004FDCBF20C43A2B4DCC22E94FDDC46.description:
explain that the goal of technology is to provide solutions to practical problems 
(ST1)[ICT F2-4.4]  

relate the concept of pH to solutions encountered in everyday life, such as pharmaceuticals, shampoo and other cleaning products, aquatic and terrestrial environments, and blood/blood products

E0F96679E360488D926BABF439E0A66D.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

DB806D6BCD944A938BF6D06335E55A0F.description: identify monoprotic and polyprotic acids and bases and compare their ionization/dissociation.

63F60EEE4B844B72B4CE3E1E1496EEF9.description: differentiate, qualitatively, between strong and weak acids and between strong and weak bases on the basis of ionization and dissociation; i.e., pH, reaction rate and electrical conductivity

01BD0EBBFF294DBE8E453D0DDD535CE0.description: define neutralization as a reaction between hydronium and hydroxide ions

8CD87A47B99047F499BF514769B6CFFF.description: define Arrhenius (modified) bases as substances that produce OH-(aq) in aqueous solutions and recognize that the definition is limited

EC221504B15C4EC3BF5A84C32338711E.description: define Arrhenius (modified) acids as substances that produce H3O+(aq) in aqueous solutions and recognize that the definition is limited

9FBDD45A54334B9FB5408F1BBF015A32.description: explain how the use of indicators, pH paper or pH meters can be used to measure H3O+(aq)

4A51BED0AAD54F278A49B292C5DBC26F.description: compare magnitude changes in pH and pOH with changes in concentration for acids and bases

F1247A0284ED48098C02A3844A6FE78D.description: use appropriate Système international (SI) units to communicate the concentration of solutions and express pH and concentration answers to the correct number of significant digits; i.e., use the number of decimal places in the pH to determine the number of significant digits of the concentration

6C890785AC2B4B90AAC10A873E0D5864.description: calculate H3O+(aq) and OH-(aq) concentrations and the pH and pOH of acidic and basic solutions based on logarithmic expressions; i.e., pH = -log[H3O+] and pOH = -log[OH-]

6671AA945CB843948E979BC1C20B5E53.description: recall the empirical definitions of acidic, basic and neutral solutions determined by using indicators, pH and electrical conductivity

EC7DCDC1F9B74B99B19F9EEE0E26F074.description: recall International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature of acids and bases

21C17D8A401F4EBE955111E405BF65DA.description: Students will describe acidic and basic solutions qualitatively and quantitatively.

6ADFB72458C044328F466C8BF26AC9E7.description:
Communication and Teamwork: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results  • compare personal concentration data with the data collected by other individuals or groups 
(CT-SEC4)   • select and use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results 
(CT-NS2)   • use integrated software effectively and efficiently to incorporate data, graphics and text 
(CT-ST2)[ICT P4-4.3]  • conduct, collectively, a risk-benefit analysis of the pollution of waterways by the release of effluents and propose a plan for reducing the impact on the ecosystem 
(IP-SEC3)(AI-SEC3)(CT-SEC1)[ICT F3-4.1]

7C103F6B11E4446A899658F6D05FA204.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions  •  use experimental data to determine the concentration of a solution 
(AI-NS3)[ICT C6-4.1]   • evaluate the risks involved in the handling, storage and disposal of solutions commonly used in the laboratory and in the home 
(AI-SEC2)(PR-NS5)

9A2541A855294491BAAF7A5DE450405A.description:
Performing and Recording: conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information • use a conductivity apparatus to differentiate solutions 
(PR-NS2)[ICT C6-4.4]   • perform an experiment to determine the concentration of a solution 
(PR-NS3)(PR-NS5)  • use a balance and volumetric glassware to prepare solutions of specified concentrations 
(PR-NS2)(PR-NS5)   • perform an investigation to determine the solubility of a solute in a saturated solution 
(PR-ST3)(PR-NS5)[ICT C6-4.2]

9C76803DDD4D44C091F0E16393FB263B.description:
Initiating and planning: formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues  •  design a procedure to identify the type of solution 
(IP-NS2)   • design a procedure to determine the concentration of a solution containing a solid solute 
(IP-NS2)   •describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-SEC3)(PR-NS5)

85F346DD6A0446CEAA1CDA21A7AC81E5.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Nature of Science Emphasis)

7AF97230706548EF80317E2A540A7EF0.description:
explain that the appropriateness, risks and benefits of technologies need to be assessed for each potential application from a variety of perspectives, including sustainability 
(ST7)[ICT F2-4.2][ICT F3-4.1]   • explain the role of concentration in risk-benefit analyses for determining the safe limits of particular substances, such as pesticide residues, heavy metals, chlorinated or fluorinated compounds and pharmaceuticals

E369144E69294D97A3E4046656A1AFE2.description:
explain how science and technology have both intended and unintended consequences for humans and the environment 
(SEC3)[ICT F3-4.1]  • explain the significance of biomagnification in increasing the concentration of substances in an ecosystem

7027EAA167E2429FB2F3F91E23849BEE.description:
explain that scientific and technological activity may arise from, and give rise to, such personal and social values as accuracy, honesty, perseverance, tolerance, open-mindedness, critical-mindedness, creativity and curiosity 
(SEC5)  • explain the Responsible Care program developed by the Canadian Chemical Producers' Association

570E0B9DCBE04FE18295AB9B2D88D266.description:
explain that science and technology have influenced, and been influenced by, historical development and societal needs 
(SEC2)[ICT F2-4.8]  • compare the ways in which concentrations of solutions are expressed in chemistry laboratories, household products and environmental studies

AC9CE7FC2D3349CCA5E3EF4A60CF9AEF.description:
explain how science and technology are developed to meet societal needs and expand human capability 
(SEC1)[ICT F2-4.8]  • provide examples of how solutions and solution concentrations are applied in products and processes, scientific studies and daily life

8414806782874B25B4F1C9CA07E81562.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

0F08D1F5702E4F5E84D4A51261A6244F.description: describe the procedures and calculations required for preparing and diluting solutions.

DF512079ACCF46FA8B90D3BDD8930C90.description: explain a saturated solution in terms of equilibrium; i.e., equal rates of dissolving and crystallization

B0E9C9075AB7410DB06123C79510E874.description: define solubility and identify related factors; i.e., temperature, pressure and miscibility

565B4D87CD29471A8FF816EB7AE89A91.description: use data and ionization/dissociation equations to calculate the concentration of ions in a solution

740F5AA0EB9F458AA6FE569F42515166.description: calculate the concentrations and/or volumes of diluted solutions and the quantities of a solution and water to use when diluting

516AA4B053994CE8A095EC4D4A7613A4.description: calculate, from empirical data, the concentration of solutions in moles per litre of solution and determine mass or volume from such concentrations

675ED270621940B796EC6624EFFCFE9E.description: express concentration in various ways; i.e., moles per litre of solution, percent by mass and parts per million

1A715EB1A2054AF0BDE1DC059E44B72A.description: explain dissolving as an endothermic or exothermic process with respect to the breaking and forming of bonds

151BE89AB36240BA80C7AC5F4315282D.description: provide examples from living and nonliving systems that illustrate how dissolving substances in water is often a prerequisite for chemical change

BED20B75BE734A9F9C29C4A570A5CCB1.description: recall the categories of pure substances and mixtures and explain the nature of homogeneous mixtures

F4004E65AEF544619FC1E2E9F05D9A26.description: Students will investigate solutions, describing their physical and chemical properties.

EFAD8237829541E894FB0398854365FC.description: Unit C: Matter as Solutions, Acids & Bases

628197210006404B8E7EA2684E9E1D12.description:
Communication and Teamwork: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results  • communicate questions, ideas and intentions and receive, interpret, understand, support and respond to the ideas of others while collecting data on gases 
(CT-NS1)  • prepare a group presentation, using multimedia, to illustrate how the pressure, temperature, volume and amount of a gas determines the universal gas constant (R) 
(CT-NS2)[ICT P3-4.1]

7F5E8BAE6AE547AC89CA27584CF9FFFF.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting:  analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions •  graph and analyze experimental data that relate pressure and temperature to gas volume 
(AI-NS2)  • identify the limitations of measurement 
(AI-NS4)  • identify a gas based on an analysis of experimental data 
(AI-NS2)[ICT C7-4.2]

B04D2BE8FBFB4D3F8F7AA8BFD639C5D7.description:
Performing and Recording:  conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information  •  perform an experiment, in which variables are identified and controlled, to illustrate gas laws 
(PR-NS3)(PR-NS5)[ICT C6-4.2][ICT F1-4.2]  • use thermometers, balances and other measuring devices effectively to collect data on gases 
(PR-NS3)[ICT F1-4.2]  • use library and electronic research tools to collect information on real and ideal gases and on applications of gases, such as hot air and weather balloons 
(PR-NS1)[ICT C1-4.1][ICT C1-4.2]  •perform an investigation to determine molar mass from gaseous volume 
(PR-NS3)(AI-NS6)[ICT C6-4.2]

307CEA7C7B994C7EAAD9F60644C80A6A.description:
Initiating and Planning:  formulate questions about observed relationships; plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues •  state hypotheses and make predictions based on information about the pressure, temperature and volume of a gas 
(IP-NS3)  • describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-NS4)  • design an experiment to illustrate Boyle's and/or Charles's gas laws 
(IP-NS2)  • design an investigation to determine the universal gas constant (R) or absolute zero 
(IP-NS2)  • explore how people who are connected with the land, such as Aboriginal peoples and agricultural workers, have used plant and animal responses to changes in atmospheric pressure as indicators of changing weather 
(IP-NS1)

DCB3AE5B5B034BD59E851AC2B2137836.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Nature of Science Emphasis)

88B97C98919F4BAFBAEF5C0D20245B9D.description:
explain that the goal of science is knowledge about the natural world 
(NS1) •  describe examples of natural phenomena and processes and products (such as breathing, diffusion, weather, hot air balloons, scuba diving equipment, automobile air bags, gas turbines and internal combustion engines) that illustrate the properties of gases.

B14DAAE7308C4CFC94BC25BC0009CA9D.description:
explain that science provides a conceptual and theoretical basis for predicting, interpreting and explaining natural and technological phenomena 
(NS5)  • describe how the development of technologies capable of precise measurements of temperature and pressure (such as thermocouples, thermistors and Bourdon gauges) led to a better understanding of gases and to the formulation of the gas laws

22F37C1E71D84B68B2E9E8A5B26CAC6A.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Nature of Science Emphasis)

2775F2DE94AC4A888C76B6E9A5CD44CD.description: illustrate how Boyle's and Charles's laws, individually and combined, are related to the ideal gas law (PV = nRT )  • express pressure in a variety of ways, including units of kilopascals, atmospheres and millimetres of mercury  • perform calculations, based on the gas laws, under STP, SATP and other defined conditions.

13836BC35FD8400FBFE5049874F7975F.description: explain the law of combining volumes

F87EBF4B2A1240079680550288247F2E.description: convert between the Celsius and Kelvin temperature scales

D551A62698494529BED7564F78972049.description: describe and compare the behaviour of real and ideal gases in terms of kinetic molecular theory

7F69933A8C93463ABA1E30F7DBE17B45.description: Students will explain molecular behaviour, using models of the gaseous state of matter.

DD43E1083D5F4DEEA19A355C3F61BD16.description: Unit B: Forms of Matter: Gases

F1A30405C6FF4483A73F7603F53D4F19.description:
Communication and Teamwork:  work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results   • analyze and evaluate, objectively, models and graphs constructed by others 
(CT-NS3)   • research the ways that scientists develop and analyze new materials 
(PR-NS1)[ICT C2-4.1]

276511A08822401CA3E12E93CC252FAE.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions   • graph and analyze data, for trends and patterns, on the melting and boiling points of a related series of molecular substances 
(AI-NS2)[ICT C7-4.2]

B5B2763B5A064D6089C3BAD7B0F77CA1.description:
Performing and Recording:  conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information  •  build models depicting the structure of simple covalent molecules, including selected organic compounds 
(CT-NS2)  • carry out an investigation to determine the melting or boiling point of a molecular substance 
(PR-NS3)(PR-NS5)   •use a thermometer and a conductivity apparatus to collect data 
(PR-NS2)   •carry out an investigation to compare the physical properties of molecular substances 
(PR-NS3)[ICT F1-4.2]

64D9A320D6EA4E66BEDA183422503922.description:
Initiating and Planning:  formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues  •  state a hypothesis and make a prediction about the properties of molecular substances based on attractive forces; e.g., melting or boiling point, enthalpies of fusion and vaporization 
(IP-NS3)  •describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-NS4)

816AF432F9CB4486A67C6CFCF8C355FF.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Nature of Science Emphasis)

C05F3B6F7CEB4D28B6877FC3C8BC6FB7.description:
explain that scientific knowledge is subject to change as new evidence becomes apparent and as laws and theories are tested and subsequently revised, reinforced or rejected 
(NS4)   • explain how scientific research and technology interact in the production and distribution of beneficial materials, such as polymers, household products and solvents  • investigate how basic knowledge about the structure of matter is advanced through nanotechnology research and development.

47070B22F8D740C6B1EA696BA9C56598.description:
explain that scientific knowledge and theories develop through hypotheses, the collection of evidence, investigation and the ability to provide explanations 
(NS2)  • relate chemical properties to predicted intermolecular bonding by investigating melting and boiling points

E557D3CA3FA347F9A81A7053E6EF473A.description:
explain that the goal of science is knowledge about the natural world 
(NS1) •  identify everyday processes and products in which molecular substances are significant, such as in the composition of household products and foods and in life processes  • identify examples of processes and products in which molecular substances are significant, such as in the use of adhesives and rubber by Aboriginal peoples

6EBB7697DA224FDC930931A2A27BC171.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Nature of Science Emphasis)

30D1F3354E024617AD8F9EFCA30AD72F.description: describe bonding as a continuum ranging from complete electron transfer to equal sharing of electrons.

5A0B6B570433471A8B08A1C23E07A1C9.description: determine the polarity of a molecule based on simple structural shapes and unequal charge distribution

19DB6675CA88497595CDC2DA8DBED478.description: relate properties of substances (e.g., melting and boiling points, enthalpies of fusion and vaporization) to the predicted intermolecular bonding in the substances

D3189FD656C5484AB9ABB15AC0E33822.description: explain intermolecular forces, London (dispersion) forces, dipole-dipole forces and hydrogen bonding

49E39EDB9DE648408A91A17B67F875A9.description: illustrate, by drawing or by building models, the structure of simple molecular substances

56E1C9873F2D4883BE124D8F8DF4F27B.description: apply VSEPR theory to predict molecular shapes for linear, angular (V-shaped, bent), tetrahedral, trigonal pyramidal and trigonal planar molecules

C474A3720CF34EDEA86109FDA608F5F5.description: draw electron dot diagrams of atoms and molecules, writing structural formulas for molecular substances and using Lewis structures to predict bonding in simple molecules

2E4DBE10216D43DBB401F2B77AF61A1A.description: relate electron pairing to multiple and covalent bonds

1DFC3E14D28F49DCB4CB01480D3119B8.description: explain why formulas for molecular substances refer to the number of atoms of each constituent element

FD010B226B304010B061CCA3BB0558C4.description: recall principles for assigning names to molecular substances

7A45F2D179104CFDB9A4ABA0D399D2F6.description: Students will describe the role of modelling, evidence and theory in explaining and understanding the structure, chemical bonding and properties of molecular substances.

A2113C5C18AB4C3799CA54FF2F3286C9.description:
Communication and Teamwork: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results •  use appropriate Système international (SI) units, fundamental and derived units and significant digits 
(CT-NS2)* • use appropriate numeric, symbolic, graphical and linguistic modes of representation to communicate ideas, plans and results 
(CT-NS2)* • analyze, critically, models of ionic compounds built by others 
(CT-NS3)        *To be developed throughout the course.

3BCB41F360724EA884BF86DEA8E250E8.description:
Analyzing and Interpreting: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions • analyze experimental data to determine the properties of ionic compounds 
(AI-NS6)[ICT C7-4.2] • use data from various sources to predict the strength of bonds between ions 
(PR-NS1)(AI-NS2)[ICT C6-4.1]

CACB1FF3B45D4DF68754C958D6AB99E8.description:
Performing and Recording:  conduct investigations into relationships among observable variables and use a broad range of tools and techniques to gather and record data and information •  draw electron dot diagrams	
(CT-NS2) • build models of ionic solids 
(CT-NS2) • perform an investigation to illustrate properties of ionic compounds 
(PR-NS3)(PR-NS5) • use the periodic table to make predictions about bonding and nomenclature 
(PR-NS1)(AI-NS1)  •use model-building software to collect and integrate information on the structure of ionic crystals 
(PR-NS4)[ICT C6-4.4]

8B47FDFF826A432F9817B490FCEBB0E5.description:
Initiating and Planning:   formulate questions about observed relationships and plan investigations of questions, ideas, problems and issues  • design an investigation to determine the properties of ionic compounds (solubility, conductivity and melting point 
(IP-NS2) • describe procedures for the safe handling, storage and disposal of materials used in the laboratory, with reference to WHMIS and consumer product labelling information 
(IP-NS4) • research the question, "Should all scientific research have a practical application?" 
(IP-NS1)[ICT C2-4.1] • design an experiment to explore the formation of ionic compounds 
(IP-NS2)

13EAAF42381749D8A5C48268C4247BE2.description: Specific Outcomes for Skills (Nature of Science Emphasis)

047FAEC4CEC54AAFB7BA41FBB02B9482.description:
explain that scientific knowledge may lead to the development of new technologies, and new technologies may lead to or facilitate scientific discovery 
(ST4)[ICT F2-4.4][ICT F2-4.8]  • explain how scientific research and technology interact in the production and distribution of beneficial materials, such as semiconductors, ceramics and composite materials.

54A7C37F193C4F5B8731C9F687794D73.description:
explain that scientific knowledge and theories develop through hypotheses, the collection of evidence, investigation and the ability to provide explanations 
(NS2)  • describe how an understanding of electronegativity contributes to knowledge of relative bond strength, melting points and boiling points of ionic compounds

80E0BCFB704643AD871C60090B60FFC6.description:
explain that the goal of science is knowledge about the natural world 
(NS1)   • identify everyday processes and products in which ionic compounds are significant, such as in the composition of household products and foods and in life processes

95C2A13007DD440AAE11781E824C27F5.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Nature of Science Emphasis)

F2E06A830AC840FD9A318DB2DAD51BA6.description: explain that ionic compounds form lattices and that these structures relate to the compounds' properties; e.g., melting point, solubility, reactivity.

C7B5CA2F754F4814A253EB735541B3D0.description: explain how an ionic bond results from the simultaneous attraction of oppositely charged ions

E7908AD75187401B9E66A30E899E5771.description: use the periodic table and electron dot diagrams to support and explain ionic bonding theory

B8D9FF7AF6914A2B8F65DDC80BC0349A.description: define valence electron, electronegativity, ionic bond and intramolecular force

A5B4C1E7BD234B53AAD15586111D7036.description: explain why formulas for ionic compounds refer to the simplest whole-number ratio of ions that result in a net charge of zero

841E762E98974234AF031B1E09D53010.description: recall principles for assigning names to ionic compounds

48475472056E494889839A19746B5209.description: Students will describe the role of modelling, evidence and theory in explaining and understanding the structure, chemical bonding and properties of ionic compounds.

8A429A9E8009448A98710C3E1F2A2935.description: The Diversity of Matter & Chemical Bonding

6A9E4B14B7D94874BE6EC27D2EB854B0.description: e.g. clean up after an activity and dispose of materials in a safe place according to safety guidelines.

34E3243AC4A44C78A8476CE0FA40BDCE.description: e.g.  assume responsibility for the safety of all those who share a common working environment

02187ECDC3A9491F8C9A0D93BFC61044.description: e.g. keep the work station uncluttered, with only appropriate laboratory materials present

868C3E44F0A24B2DA1654AFF043FD7EC.description: e.g. use minimal quantities of chemicals when performing experiments

4F832EC2ED204B6DADF9E327845F939E.description: e.g. recognize the significant role that chemical researchers and the chemical industry play in identifying risks and developing guidelines for safe exposure

E963292F3F3B4F909145CECD03754540.description: e.g. value the need for safe handling and storage of chemicals

4864BCA82BD34112A968036683720F1D.description: e.g. treat equipment with respect and manipulate materials carefully

023715D78AF9400783CD4E70E42462D0.description: Students will be encouraged to: show concern for safety in planning, carrying out and reviewing activities, referring to the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) and consumer product labelling information;

E90DE6DA8E6C49CA8837D7AEE98B0FED.description: e.g. evaluate the contributions of technological innovations to quality of life and care of the environment.

F34B8019159040A5A7DB2B35EDBB8A96.description: e.g. develop an awareness that the application of technology has risks and benefits

C1C81CE97BF24A2783E65CC163BE4110.description: e.g. consider a variety of perspectives when addressing issues, weighing scientific, technological, economic, political and ecological factors

418086773C8D4B2EB0878C3201C663BF.description: e.g. remain critical-minded regarding the short- and long-term consequences of human actions

1A2612156000438BAC35B83B96F7ED94.description: e.g. evaluate, willingly, the impact of their own choices or the choices scientists make when they carry out an investigation

126E0D8177A74635941B4D3D18EF07FC.description: Students will be encouraged to: demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment;

0856706D25C04BC1A8D6CE942726F648.description: e.g. seek the points of view of others and consider a multitude of perspectives.

1841D940CFB64B8498CB818DE28868A0.description: e.g. evaluate the ideas of others objectively

62EB7222A1D74BBC846DD21E2C0C9B09.description: e.g. accept responsibility for any task that helps the group complete an activity

38FA97B809234B509C6A3DC77471E241.description: e.g. assume a variety of roles within a group, as required

D6D49A8E7E8D4A6EA9A8F73216C20644.description: Students will be encouraged to: demonstrate sensitivity and responsibility in pursuing a balance between the needs of humans and a sustainable environment;

3BB052F4ED6A4D8CAEDB6DCC6E6107A0.description: e.g. value the role of precise observation and careful experimentation in learning about chemistry.

F4135CB4D28C47D89A4CB1FD48686F34.description: e.g. appreciate that scientific evidence is the foundation for generalizations and explanations about chemistry

D962659FC874452AA7467FCF5B87FC85.description: e.g. appreciate the limited nature of evidence when interpreting observed phenomena

BD27D2AAB01F4E5BB0FAB99681A4A0FF.description: e.g. tolerate the uncertainty involved in providing explanations and theoretical definitions

924755CE01D44CACAE6DA40307379008.description: e.g. develop curiosity about the nature of chemistry

DFACA850A3D146478E5E90CFD24B457E.description: Students will be encouraged to seek and apply evidence when evaluating alternative approaches to investigations, problems and issues;

D1F14AC7DC2B44688051F5D0F1B67E88.description: e.g. recognize the research contributions of Canadians.

BBFAD5B8F9014DE1B6A282365F7AFFE7.description: e.g. recognize the research contributions of both men and women

2E07014B59CF40189FE2D5CCC3A720AE.description: e.g. recognize the contributions of various peoples and cultures in advancing understanding and applications of chemistry

2062FFC18CAA479F9823426CD55F699E.description: e.g. recognize that the scientific approach is one of many ways of viewing the universe

0C280C4AE19C41C8989031CA4EC2ED38.description: e.g. investigate how early peoples developed recipes for common foods, cleaners and remedies

B53FC0BFB5644CABBC2011866F635CE7.description: e.g. research the role of chemistry in the International Space Station project

CBD06034D7264F49AFAF88E5AC558B49.description: e.g. value traditional knowledge of common solutions and substances

AFD6708DD51E41B1AACDE99F9415FD16.description: e.g. trace, from a historical perspective, how the observations and experimental work of many individuals led to modern understandings of matter

0BC3CE7CDC1E4DD7B133706DDDC33897.description: e.g. recognize that theories develop as a result of the sharing of ideas by many scientists

E2BE3F593EC34A0FBD994666600D3C57.description: e.g. use a multiperspective approach, considering scientific, technological, economic, cultural, political and environmental factors when formulating conclusions, solving problems or making decisions on an STS issue

23CDEA7FFE5B4C0398BD8CAA32C5E1F6.description: Students will be encouraged to: appreciate that scientific understanding evolves from the interaction of ideas involving people with different views and backgrounds;

13022F9D2C034C6C859C7A874D1831FE.description: e.g.identify industrial, commercial and household processes and products and associated careers that require a knowledge of quantitative analysis.

A2493986588546ACB6A2C64F40E9F69B.description: e.g.develop an awareness of the relationship between chemical principles and applications of chemistry

7DBDDB04DFC44FB79D0F1D014B76D6EA.description: e.g.express interest in science and technology topics not directly related to their formal studies

E36BE3F57A9F4DBA841650CDB4F6C8BE.description: e.g.develop a questioning attitude and a desire to understand more about matter

5D8F5DCAEDCB4596AFEC04A8B312DF6C.description: e.g.develop an interest in the role of chemistry in daily life

9C23EECB4F7A4F6EB91F4732AB8EFA15.description: e.g.investigate careers in fields such as food science, engineering, laboratory technology, environmental chemistry, agriculture, water treatment and forensic science

60180BE72B1A45B59073F0FF63CDB141.description: e.g.appreciate the usefulness of models and theories in helping explain the structure and behaviour of matter

5D311CA96CB54DBE8883185D665F09BF.description: e.g. appreciate how scientific problem solving and new technologies are related
